info.name: API Springboot demo
info.description:
# ðŸš€ Get started here

This documentation provides details on how to interact with API endpoints using Postman.

## ðŸ”– Endpoints

## Category

### 1\. Get all Categories

**Endpoint:** `/category`  
**Method:** `GET`  
**Description:** Retrieve a paginated list of all categories.

#### Request:

- **Parameters:**
    
    - `page` (optional, default 0) â€“ Page number.
        
    - `size` (optional, default 20) â€“ Number of items per page.
        
    - `sort` (optional) â€“ Sort fields, e.g., `name,desc,id,asc`.
        

### 2\. Get Category by ID

**Endpoint:** `/category/{id}`  
**Method:** `GET`  
**Description:** Retrieve details of a specific category by its ID.

#### Request:

- **Parameters:**
    
    - `id` (Path variable) â€“ The ID of the category.
        

### 3\. Search Categories by Name

**Endpoint:** `/category/search`  
**Method:** `GET`  
**Description:** Search categories by name.

#### Request:

- **Parameters:**
    
    - `name` (Query parameter) â€“ The name of the category to search.
        
    - `page`, `size`, `sort` (optional, default as above).
        

### 4\. Create Category

**Endpoint:** `/category`  
**Method:** `POST`  
**Description:** Create a new category.

#### Request:

- **Body:**
    

``` json
{
  "name": "New Category"
}

 ```

### 5\. Update Category

**Endpoint:** `/category/{id}`  
**Method:** `PUT`  
**Description:** Update an existing category by ID.

#### Request:

- **Parameters:**
    
    - `id` (Path variable) â€“ The ID of the category to update.
        
- **Body:**
    

``` json
{
  "name": "Updated Category"
}
ï»¿

 ```

### 6\. Delete Category

**Endpoint:** `/category/{id}`  
**Method:** `DELETE`  
**Description:** Delete a category by ID.

#### Request:

- **Parameters:**
    
    - `id` (Path variable) â€“ The ID of the category to delete.
        

## Topic

### 1\. Get all Topics

**Endpoint:** `/topic`  
**Method:** `GET`  
**Description:** Retrieve a paginated list of all topics.

#### Request:

- **Parameters:**
    
    - `page`, `size`, `sort` (optional, default as above).
        

### 2\. Get Topic by ID

**Endpoint:** `/topic/{id}`  
**Method:** `GET`  
**Description:** Retrieve details of a specific topic by its ID.

#### Request:

- **Parameters:**
    
    - `id` (Path variable) â€“ The ID of the topic.
        

### 3\. Get Topics by Category ID

**Endpoint:** `/topic/category/{id}`  
**Method:** `GET`  
**Description:** Retrieve a list of topics belonging to a specific category.

#### Request:

- **Parameters:**
    
    - `id` (Path variable) â€“ The ID of the category.
        

### 4\. Search Topics by Title

**Endpoint:** `/topic/search`  
**Method:** `GET`  
**Description:** Search topics by title.

#### Request:

- **Parameters:**
    
    - `title` (Query parameter) â€“ The title to search for.
        
    - `page`, `size`, `sort` (optional, default as above).
        

### 5\. Create Topic

**Endpoint:** `/topic`  
**Method:** `POST`  
**Description:** Create a new topic.

#### Request:

- **Body:**
    

``` json
{
  "title": "New Topic",
  "categoryId": 1
}

 ```

### 6\. Update Topic

**Endpoint:** `/topic/{id}`  
**Method:** `PUT`  
**Description:** Update an existing topic by ID.

#### Request:

- **Parameters:**
    
    - `id` (Path variable) â€“ The ID of the topic to update.
        
- **Body:**
    

``` json
{
  "title": "Updated Topic"
}

 ```

### 7\. Delete Topic

**Endpoint:**Â `/topic/{id}`  
**Method:**Â `DELETE`  
**Description:**Â Delete a topic by ID.

#### Request:

- **Parameters:**
    
    - `id`Â (Path variable) â€“ The ID of the topic to delete.

request.description:
This is a POST request, submitting data to an API via the request body. This request submits JSON data, and the data is reflected in the response.

A successful POST request typically returns a `200 OK` or `201 Created` response code.

response.name: 400 - Name must not be blank

request.description:
This is a GET request and it is used to "get" data from an endpoint. There is no request body for a GET request, but you can use query parameters to help specify the resource you want data on (e.g., in this request, we have `id=1`).

A successful GET response will have a `200 OK` status, and should include some kind of response body - for example, HTML web content or JSON data.

response.name: 200 - Get categories

request.description:
This is a GET request and it is used to "get" data from an endpoint. There is no request body for a GET request, but you can use query parameters to help specify the resource you want data on (e.g., in this request, we have `id=1`).

A successful GET response will have a `200 OK` status, and should include some kind of response body - for example, HTML web content or JSON data.

query.description: Sort by name [DESC] and id , createdAt[ASC]

response.name: 200 - Filter category by name

query.description: Sort by name [DESC] and id , createdAt[ASC]

request.description:
This is a PUT request and it is used to overwrite an existing piece of data. For instance, after you create an entity with a POST request, you may want to modify that later. You can do that using a PUT request. You typically identify the entity being updated by including an identifier in the URL (eg. `id=1`).

A successful PUT request typically returns a `200 OK`, `201 Created`, or `204 No Content` response code.

This is a DELETE request, and it is used to delete data that was previously created via a POST request. You typically identify the entity being updated by including an identifier in the URL (eg. `id=1`).

A successful DELETE request typically returns a `200 OK`, `202 Accepted`, or `204 No Content` response code.
